Comment: The monarch being the head of state in the UK is mostly ceremonial. I mean, Churchill went to Potsdam and Yalta. He delivered the Iron Curtain speech in the US midwest. It was Blair that met with Bush to discuss the Iraq War. The list goes on. For all intents and purposes of actual governance, the PM is the Head of State.  And I think it's kind of silly to suggest that the UK and its commonwealth partners aren't republics. Yes, there is a monarchy that nominally is at the top of the org chart, so to speak, but the king doesn't have any real power, and all thing related to politics, governance, legislation, etc are connected to standard republican structures. The constitutional monarchy is a republic already.  But yeah, if you wanted to abolish the monarchy you very much could. The king doesn't actually wield power by design, but operates more a legitimacy-building structure. But if the people no longer want a king, they could get rid of the king without impacting their political system hardly at all.

Comment: Eh, even then, that's not really fair. Lords has been severely reformed over the years. The body is no longer hereditary, though it is appointed to life terms. The body also has had its legislative roles strictly reduced in accordance with its non-elected nature. It can introduce bills, sure, and does have the power to essentially reject a bill...though Commons can simply override that rejection in many cases anyway.  In essence, Lords is today's incarnation is much more similar to the SCOTUS than the US Senate. If Lords makes the UK not a republic, then I would say the SCOTUS does the same for the US.
